question:
Which of the following river valleys is NOT known for coal deposits in India ?

SSC MTS 15/10/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Coal deposits in India are mostly found in Gondwana rock formations, which are abundant in central and eastern parts of the country.
  • The Satluj River valley, located in the northern part of India (Himachal Pradesh and Punjab region), is not geologically associated with coal-rich formations.
  • Mahanadi, Godavari, and Son river valleys are part of the Gondwana coal-bearing regions and are known for major coalfields.
  • Thus, Satluj Valley lacks significant coal deposits, making it the correct answer.

Additional Information:

  • Major coalfields in Mahanadi basin: Talcher, Ib Valley
  • Godavari basin: Singareni, Wardha Valley
  • Son basin: Singrauli, Sohagpur
  • Satluj is part of the Indus river system, not the Gondwana basin.

question:
Which of the following is a precious mineral?

SSC MTS 18/10/2024(2nd Shift)
solution:
• Platinum is a rare and highly valuable precious metal used in jewelry, medical instruments, and catalytic converters.
  • It is classified as a precious mineral due to its rarity, economic value, and industrial importance.
  • Hematite is an iron ore, primarily used in steel production.
  • Bauxite is the chief ore of aluminum.
  • Mica is a non-metallic mineral used in insulation and electronics but not considered precious.

Additional Information:

  • India has platinum group element (PGE) prospects in states like Odisha and Tamil Nadu.
  • Platinum is often found with nickel and copper ores.

question:
The Panchpatmali mineral deposit region is located in which state from the following?

SSC MTS 22/10/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• Panchpatmali is a well-known bauxite mineral deposit located in the Koraput district of Odisha.
  • It is operated by NALCO (National Aluminium Company), a Navratna PSU.
  • The region is part of the Eastern Ghats, which are rich in aluminum ore.
  • Other states listed (Haryana, Himachal Pradesh, Rajasthan) do not have significant bauxite reserves like Panchpatmali.
  • Hence, Odisha is the correct answer.

Additional Information:

  • Panchpatmali is one of the largest bauxite reserves in India.
  • Odisha contributes significantly to India’s aluminum production through this mine.

question:
Which type of coal is found in Damodar valley?

SSC MTS 14/11/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Damodar Valley is one of the richest coal-producing regions in India, located primarily in Jharkhand and West Bengal.
  • The type of coal found here is Bituminous, which has high carbon content and is used widely in industrial and thermal power generation.
  • Anthracite is the highest grade of coal but is rare in India.
  • Lignite is low-grade brown coal found mainly in Tamil Nadu and Rajasthan.
  • Peat is the lowest grade, formed from partially decayed vegetation, not common in Damodar Valley.

Additional Information:

  • Major coalfields in Damodar Valley include Jharia, Bokaro, Raniganj, and Dhanbad.
  • Bituminous coal from this region supports India’s steel plants and power sector.

question:
Which of the following is an inosilicate amphibole mineral used in highway construction and as railroad ballast?

SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• Hornblende is an inosilicate amphibole mineral, composed of complex silicates of calcium, magnesium, iron, and aluminum.
  • It is commonly found in igneous and metamorphic rocks and has high durability, making it suitable for highway construction and railroad ballast.
  • Shale is a sedimentary rock, not used for heavy-duty construction.
  • Olivine is a nesosilicate mineral, not amphibole.
  • Geyserite is a form of opaline silica found near hot springs, not used in construction.

Additional Information:

  • Hornblende contributes to the strength and density of the rocks it’s found in, like diorite and andesite.
  • Its dark color and toughness make it valuable in industrial applications involving road and track stability.

question:
Which coal is low-grade, brown and soft with high moisture content?

SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• Lignite is a type of coal that is brownish-black, soft, and has a woody texture. It is considered the lowest grade of coal in terms of carbon content and energy output.
  • It contains 40–55% carbon and up to 45% moisture, making it inefficient for long-distance transportation and long-term storage.
  • Lignite burns with a smoky flame, produces less heat, and emits more pollutants compared to higher-grade coals.
  • It is mostly used in thermal power plants that are set up close to lignite mines, as transporting it over long distances is not economical.
  • The other options are:
    • (a) Metallurgical coal: High-grade bituminous coal used for making coke in the steel industry.
    • (c) Bituminous coal: Higher carbon content (60–80%), more efficient than lignite, used in power plants and industry.
    • (d) Anthracite: The hardest and highest carbon-content coal (90%+), burns cleanly and with the highest heat value.

Additional Information:

  • Major lignite reserves in India are found in Neyveli (Tamil Nadu), Barsingsar (Rajasthan), and parts of Gujarat and Kerala.
  • Neyveli Lignite Corporation (NLC) is one of India's largest producers of lignite-based electricity.
  • Lignite is also known as brown coal and forms at shallow depths under relatively low temperature and pressure conditions.

question:
Match the following renewable sources of energy with their producing regions in India correctly.

SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (3rd shift)


https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1749817656976_image001.png
solution:
• Tidal Energy → Gulf of Khambhat (a):

    The Gulf of Khambhat, located on the western coast of India (in Gujarat), has high tidal variations, making it ideal for tidal energy projects.

  • 2. Wind Energy → Nagercoil (b):

    Nagercoil, in Tamil Nadu, is a prominent site for wind farms due to consistent strong winds and favorable geography.

  • 3. Geo Thermal Energy → Puga Valley (c):

    The Puga Valley, located in Ladakh, is a geothermal hotspot where underground heat can be harnessed for energy production.

So the correct matching is:

1-a, 2-b, 3-c → Option (b)

Additional Information:

  • India’s first tidal energy project is proposed in the Gulf of Khambhat.
  • Tamil Nadu is one of India’s leading states in wind power generation.
  • Geothermal energy in Puga Valley remains an untapped resource with future potential.

question:
The district of Shivamogga that is famous for its Iron-Ore and Manganese mineral is located in which state of India?

SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Shivamogga (Shimoga) is a district located in the state of Karnataka, in southern India.
  • It is part of the Western Ghats and is known for its rich deposits of minerals, especially iron ore and manganese.
  • Karnataka is one of the leading states in mineral production, especially of iron ore, which is found abundantly in districts like Ballari, Chitradurga, and Shivamogga.
  • The other states mentioned (Jharkhand, Maharashtra, Rajasthan) are mineral-rich but Shivamogga is not located in any of them.

Additional Information:

  • Karnataka contributes significantly to India’s steel industry due to its iron ore reserves.
  • The Sandur-Hospet region and parts of Shivamogga have several mining leases for iron and manganese.

question:
Where is the Narora Nuclear Power plant located?

SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
• The Narora Nuclear Power Plant (NNPP) is located in the Bulandshahr district of Uttar Pradesh, on the banks of the Ganga River.
  • It is one of India’s early nuclear power stations and is operated by the Nuclear Power Corporation of India Limited (NPCIL).
  • The plant has two Pressurized Heavy Water Reactors (PHWRs), each with a capacity of 220 MW.
  • Tamil Nadu (Kudankulam, Kalpakkam), Maharashtra (Tarapur), and Karnataka (Kaiga) have nuclear plants, but Narora is only in Uttar Pradesh.

Additional Information:

  • The Narora plant became operational in 1991.
  • It plays a key role in supplying electricity to northern India, especially Uttar Pradesh and surrounding states.

question:
The Mundra Thermal Power Plant is located in which district of Gujarat?

SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The Mundra Thermal Power Plant is located in the Kutch district of Gujarat.
  • It is one of the largest coal-based thermal power plants in India and is operated by Adani Power Limited.
  • The plant is situated near Mundra Port, which facilitates easy import of coal, making it a strategic location.
  • Other districts listed—Jamnagar, Kheda, Gandhinagar—do not host this power plant.

Additional Information:

  • The Mundra plant has an installed capacity of around 4620 MW.
  • It includes supercritical technology, improving efficiency and reducing emissions compared to conventional coal plants.

question:
Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh states are rich with ____________ material deposits.

SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
• Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh are among the richest states in India in terms of coal deposits.
  • These states are part of the Damodar Valley and Mahanadi basin, which include major coalfields like Jharia, Bokaro (Jharkhand) and Korba, Hasdeo-Arand (Chhattisgarh).
  • Coal from these regions supports thermal power plants, steel production, and other heavy industries.
  • Other options:
    • Gold: Found in limited quantities (e.g., Karnataka).
    • Petroleum: Major reserves in Assam, Gujarat, and offshore Mumbai.
    • Silicon: Extracted from quartz, but not a mined resource in bulk like coal.

Additional Information:

  • India's largest coal reserves are found in Jharkhand.
  • Coal India Limited (CIL) operates many mines in these two states, contributing significantly to national energy supply.

question:
The Salal Project, also called the Salal Hydroelectric Power Station, is on which river?

SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
• The Salal Hydroelectric Project is located on the Chenab River in the Reasi district of Jammu and Kashmir (now Jammu division of J&K UT).
  • It was the first hydroelectric project constructed in the state and plays a key role in power generation for northern India.
  • The Chenab River originates in Himachal Pradesh, flows through Jammu & Kashmir, and is a major tributary of the Indus River.
  • Other rivers listed:
    • Krishna flows in southern India.
    • Ganga flows through northern plains but doesn’t host the Salal Project.
    • Ravi flows through Punjab but is not associated with this project.

Additional Information:

  • The Salal Project has a total installed capacity of 690 MW (2 stages).
  • It is operated by the NHPC (National Hydroelectric Power Corporation).

question:
Identify a conventional source of energy from the following options.

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Cattle dung is a conventional source of energy traditionally used in rural areas of India and other developing countries.
  • It is commonly dried and used as fuel for cooking and heating, or processed in biogas plants for energy.
  • Conventional energy sources are those that have been used for a long time, usually biomass and fossil fuels.
  • The other options are non-conventional (renewable or modern) sources:
    • Geothermal energy comes from Earth’s internal heat.
    • Atomic energy is derived from nuclear reactions.
    • Solar power comes from sunlight and is renewable.

Additional Information:

  • India promotes biogas plants using cattle dung under the National Biogas and Organic Manure Programme (NBOMP).
  • Conventional sources are usually non-renewable, but biomass like cattle dung is an exception as it's renewable but traditional.

question:
The Durg-Bastar-Chandrapur iron ore belt lies in _____ states.

Matriculation Level 21/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
solution:
• The Durg-Bastar-Chandrapur iron ore belt is a significant mineral-rich region in central India.
  • It spans across the states of Chhattisgarh (Durg and Bastar districts) and Maharashtra (Chandrapur district).
  • This belt is known for its abundant iron ore reserves, which supply raw material to steel plants and other metal industries.
  • The other options either include states that do not lie on this belt or do not have all three named districts.

Additional Information:

  • The Bailadila range in Bastar (Chhattisgarh) is famous for high-grade iron ore and is mined by NMDC (National Mineral Development Corporation).
  • Chandrapur in Maharashtra is also known for its coal and iron ore reserves, supporting local industries and thermal power.

question:
Which of the following agencies is responsible for the operation and maintenance of the Hazira Vijaypur Jagdishpur pipeline?

Matriculation Level 21/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
option_1: Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Limited
option_2: Gas Authority of India Limited
option_3: Indian Oil Corporation Limited
option_4: Oil and Natural Gas Commission
solution:
• The Hazira–Vijaipur–Jagdishpur (HVJ) pipeline is India’s first major cross-country gas pipeline, crucial for transporting natural gas across northern and western India.
  • It is operated and maintained by Gas Authority of India Limited (GAIL).
  • GAIL is a Public Sector Undertaking (PSU) under the Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, and it specializes in natural gas processing, transmission, and distribution.
  • Other options:
    • HPCL and IOCL deal mainly with petroleum products and refining.
    • ONGC focuses on oil and gas exploration and production, not pipeline operations.

Additional Information:

  • The HVJ pipeline was commissioned in 1987, spanning over 1800 km.
  • It supplies gas to power plants, fertilizer units, and industrial hubs in states like Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, and Delhi.

question:
According to the Indian Mineral Yearbook 2018, which state alone accounts for 72% of the magnetite deposits in India?

Matriculation Level 24/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
solution:
• As per the Indian Mineral Yearbook 2018, Karnataka holds the largest share of magnetite deposits in India, accounting for approximately 72% of the country's total reserves.
  • Magnetite is a type of iron ore, valued for its high iron content and used extensively in steel production.
  • Karnataka has major magnetite-rich regions such as Chikmagalur, Chitradurga, and Bellary.
  • The other states listed—West Bengal, Maharashtra, and Tamil Nadu—have some magnetite presence, but not nearly as significant as Karnataka.

Additional Information:

  • Magnetite is one of the two main types of iron ore in India, the other being hematite.
  • Karnataka is also a key player in India’s overall iron and steel industry due to its rich mineral base and industrial infrastructure.

question:
NALCO is an Indian government enterprise, dealing with which of the following minerals?

Matriculation Level 25/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
solution:
• NALCO (National Aluminium Company Limited) is a Public Sector Undertaking (PSU) under the Ministry of Mines, Government of India.
  • It primarily deals with Bauxite, which is the raw material for producing alumina and aluminium.
  • NALCO mines bauxite mainly from Panchpatmali Hills in Odisha, and processes it in its refinery at Damanjodi.
  • The other minerals:
    • Iron is handled by companies like SAIL and NMDC.
    • Mica is used in electronics and cosmetics, but not NALCO’s focus.
    • Copper is managed by Hindustan Copper Limited.

Additional Information:

  • NALCO is a Navratna company and one of the largest integrated bauxite–alumina–aluminium–power complexes in Asia.
  • It also operates aluminium smelters and captive power plants in Angul, Odisha.

question:
Which of the following are major coal fields in India?

Matriculation Level 26/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
solution:
• Jharia (Jharkhand) and Raniganj (West Bengal) are two of the oldest and most important coalfields in India.
  • They are part of the Gondwana coal region, which contains over 98% of India’s coal reserves.
  • These coalfields provide high-grade bituminous coal, used mainly for steel production and power generation.
  • The other options are incorrect:
    • Jhunjhunu and Alwar (Rajasthan) – not known for coal, but for minerals like zinc and marble.
    • Satara and Pune (Maharashtra) – not coal-producing areas.
    • Coimbatore and Madurai (Tamil Nadu) – known for textiles and industries, not coal.

Additional Information:

  • Jharia coalfield is famous for its coking coal, essential for steel manufacturing.
  • Raniganj was the first coal mining area in India, dating back to the 18th century.

question:
Which is the world’s largest PV Solar Park located in one of the Indian states ?

Higher Secondary 20/06/2024 (Shift- 2)
solution:
• The Bhadla Solar Park, located in the Jodhpur district of Rajasthan, is the world’s largest photovoltaic (PV) solar park.
  • It spans over 14,000 acres and has an installed capacity of over 2,245 MW (megawatts).
  • The park benefits from the high solar radiation and dry climate of the Thar Desert, making it ideal for solar power generation.
  • Other options:
    • Pavagada Solar Park (Karnataka) – one of the largest in India, but smaller than Bhadla.
    • Dholera Solar Park (Gujarat) – still under development.
    • Harshad Solar Park – not a notable solar installation.

Additional Information:

  • Bhadla is operated under the Renewable Energy Corporation of Rajasthan and includes projects by companies like Adani and SB Energy.
  • It plays a critical role in achieving India’s renewable energy targets under the National Solar Mission.

question:
Tertiary coals occur in which of the following states in India ?

Graduate Level 21/06/2024 (Shift- 3)
solution:
• Tertiary coals are younger coals formed during the Tertiary period (around 15 to 60 million years ago).
  • These coals are generally lignite or sub-bituminous in nature and are found in the northeastern and southern parts of India.
  • Meghalaya, a northeastern state, has significant tertiary coal deposits, especially in districts like Jaintia Hills, Khasi Hills, and Garo Hills.
  • The other states—Uttarakhand, Bihar, and Haryana—do not have notable tertiary coal reserves.

Additional Information:

  • Meghalaya’s coal is mostly used for local industries and thermal power, although it is not suitable for metallurgical use.
  • Other states with tertiary coal: Assam, Arunachal Pradesh, Jammu & Kashmir, and Tamil Nadu.

question:
Koderma Gaya Hazaribagh belt is known for the production of which of the following minerals?

Graduate Level 25/06/2024 (Shift- 3)
solution:
• The Koderma–Gaya–Hazaribagh belt, spread across parts of Jharkhand and Bihar, is historically famous for the production of mica.
  • This region was once known as the “Mica Capital of India” and exported high-quality mica globally.
  • Mica from this region is used in electrical insulation, cosmetics, paints, and electronic components.
  • The other options:
    • Bauxite is found in Odisha, Chhattisgarh, and Maharashtra.
    • Coal is found in Dhanbad, Bokaro, and Raniganj, not prominently in this belt.
    • Copper is majorly found in Singhbhum (Jharkhand), not Koderma or Gaya.

Additional Information:

  • Mica mining in this belt has declined but still exists, often in small-scale or unorganized sectors.
  • India remains a significant producer of mica globally, despite reduced large-scale operations.

question:
Which of the following is NOT among the commercial sources of energy?

Graduate Level 26/06/2024 (Shift- 3)
solution:
• Fuel wood is not considered a commercial source of energy; it is a non-commercial or traditional energy source, mainly used in rural and tribal households for cooking and heating.
  • Commercial sources of energy are those which are purchased and traded in the market, like:
    • Petroleum – a major commercial fossil fuel used in transport and industry.
    • Electricity – commercially distributed for residential, industrial, and agricultural use.
    • Hydropower – generated by hydroelectric plants and commercially supplied through grids.
  • Fuel wood is generally gathered freely or locally, not bought from markets, hence not commercial.

Additional Information:

  • Non-commercial energy sources include fuel wood, cow dung, crop residues, etc.
  • These are still widely used in developing countries but have low energy efficiency and contribute to indoor air pollution.

question:
The Mumbai High region in the Arabian Sea is known for mining _______ .

SSC MTS 04/09/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Mumbai High region, located in the Arabian Sea about 160 km west of Mumbai, is India’s largest offshore oil field.
  • It is known for the extraction of mineral oil (crude oil), which is processed and refined into petroleum products.
  • The oil was first discovered in 1974, and commercial production began shortly thereafter.
  • Other options are incorrect:
    • Uranium is mined in Jharkhand (e.g., Jaduguda).
    • Coal is mined in states like Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, and Odisha.
    • Copper is primarily found in Madhya Pradesh and Jharkhand, not offshore.

Additional Information:

  • Mumbai High is operated by ONGC (Oil and Natural Gas Corporation).
  • It plays a major role in meeting India’s domestic crude oil needs, contributing a significant share of total production.

question:
The Gua and Noamundi mines are located in with state of India?

SSC MTS 04/09/2023 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Gua and Noamundi mines are prominent iron ore mines located in the state of Jharkhand, eastern India.
  • These mines are situated in the West Singhbhum district, which forms part of the Chotanagpur plateau – a mineral-rich region.
  • Noamundi is operated by Tata Steel, while Gua is under SAIL (Steel Authority of India Limited).
  • The other options are incorrect:
    • Assam – known for tea and petroleum, not iron ore.
    • Haryana – industrially developed but lacks major mineral mines.
    • Rajasthan – rich in marble, zinc, and limestone, but not for Gua or Noamundi mines.

Additional Information:

  • The iron ore from these mines supports steel production in Jharkhand and neighboring states.
  • Jharkhand ranks among the top states in India for mineral production, especially iron, coal, and mica.

question:
According to the Indian Minerals Yearbook 2020, which state has the highest production of manganese in India ?

SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• As per the Indian Minerals Yearbook 2020, Madhya Pradesh ranks first in manganese production in India.
  • The state contributes the largest share (over 30%) of the country's total manganese output.
  • Key manganese-producing districts in Madhya Pradesh include Balaghat, Chhindwara, and Jabalpur.
  • The mineral is primarily used in the steel industry for making ferroalloys and improving the hardness of steel.
  • Other options:
    • Maharashtra and Odisha are also major producers but rank below Madhya Pradesh.
    • Karnataka has moderate production levels.

Additional Information:

  • Balaghat district alone is among the richest manganese-producing areas in Asia.
  • Manganese is also essential in battery production and chemical industries.

question:
Which district of Madhya Pradesh is a leading producer of copper?

SSC CHSL 10/08/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Balaghat district in Madhya Pradesh is the leading producer of copper in the state and one of the few copper-producing regions in India.
  • The Malanjkhand Copper Project, located in Balaghat, is India’s largest open-pit copper mine.
  • This mine is operated by Hindustan Copper Limited (HCL), a PSU under the Ministry of Mines.
  • The other options:
    • Jabalpur is known for limestone and dolomite.
    • Bhopal is an administrative and industrial hub, not mineral-rich.
    • Gwalior is known for sandstone, not copper.

Additional Information:

  • The Malanjkhand deposit contains both copper ore and associated minerals like gold, silver, and molybdenum.
  • Copper is a vital metal used in electrical wiring, electronics, and alloys.

question:
Which of the following is an open pit copper mine ?

SSC CHSL 11/08/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• Malanjkhand in Balaghat district, Madhya Pradesh is India’s largest open-pit copper mine.
  • It is operated by Hindustan Copper Limited (HCL) and is a key site for copper ore extraction in India.
  • The mine uses open-cast (open-pit) mining techniques, meaning the minerals are extracted from a pit excavated on the surface.
  • Other options:
    • Bastar (Chhattisgarh) is known for iron ore, not for copper.
    • Singhbhum (Jharkhand) is a copper-rich region but consists of mostly underground copper mines.
    • Ballari (Karnataka) is famous for iron ore, not copper.

Additional Information:

  • The Malanjkhand mine also yields associated minerals like gold and silver.
  • It plays a vital role in supporting India’s electrical, electronics, and alloy industries through copper production.

question:
Which of the following regions in India is nicknamed as the storehouse of minerals?

SSC CHSL 17/08/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• The Chota Nagpur Plateau, located in eastern India, is commonly known as the “storehouse of minerals” due to its vast reserves of metallic and non-metallic minerals.
  • This region covers parts of Jharkhand, Odisha, Chhattisgarh, and West Bengal.
  • It is rich in coal, iron ore, bauxite, copper, mica, uranium, and other essential minerals.
  • Other options:
    • Deccan Plateau – known more for black soil and agriculture.
    • Western Ghats – known for biodiversity, not minerals.
    • Himalayas – geologically young and unstable, not rich in mineral deposits.

Additional Information:

  • Major mining centers in the Chota Nagpur region include Dhanbad, Bokaro, Jharia, Singhbhum, and Hazaribagh.
  • This mineral-rich plateau supports India’s steel industry, thermal power, and heavy engineering sectors.

question:
What are the main energy sources for earth's internal heat engine?

SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (4th shift)
option_1: Radiogenic heat and oceanic tide heat
option_2: Heat from volcanoes and solar heat
option_3: Solar heat and oceanic tide heat
option_4: Radiogenic heat and primordial heat
solution:
• The Earth’s internal heat engine is powered primarily by two main sources:
    • Radiogenic heat: Heat generated by the radioactive decay of isotopes such as uranium-238, thorium-232, and potassium-40 in the Earth's mantle and crust.
    • Primordial heat: Residual heat from the Earth's formation about 4.6 billion years ago, due to accretion and differentiation.
  • These heat sources drive geological processes like plate tectonics, mantle convection, earthquakes, and volcanic activity.
  • Other options (like solar heat, tides, or volcanoes) may affect the surface but do not contribute significantly to internal Earth processes.

Additional Information:

  • Around 50% of Earth’s internal heat is believed to come from radiogenic sources, and the rest from primordial heat.
  • This internal heat is essential for sustaining Earth’s geodynamo, which creates the planet’s magnetic field.

question:
The Bailadila range of Chhattisgarh is famous for which of the following minerals?

SSC CGL 17/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The Bailadila range, located in the Dantewada district of Chhattisgarh, is renowned for its high-grade iron ore deposits.
  • The iron ore found here has a high iron content (about 66%) and low impurities, making it ideal for steel manufacturing.
  • It is one of India’s most significant iron ore regions, and mining operations here are conducted by NMDC (National Mineral Development Corporation).
  • Other options:
    • Copper is found in places like Malanjkhand (Madhya Pradesh).
    • Bauxite is mainly mined in Odisha, Maharashtra, and parts of Chhattisgarh.
    • Coal is found in Korba and Raigarh (Chhattisgarh), but not Bailadila.

Additional Information:

  • The Bailadila range is named for its hump-like shape (Baila = ox, Dila = hump).
  • It has multiple mining sectors, such as Deposit 5, 10, and 14, contributing heavily to India’s iron export, especially to Japan and China.

question:
The approximate amount of silica present in cement is:

SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Silica (SiO₂) is one of the key components of Portland cement, contributing to the strength and durability of the final product.
  • In cement, silica combines with calcium oxide (CaO) to form calcium silicates, which are responsible for the setting and hardening of cement.
  • The approximate percentage of silica in cement typically lies between 17% and 25%, depending on the grade and type of cement.
  • Other options represent ranges that are either too low or too high for typical cement composition.

Additional Information:

  • Standard composition of Portland cement:
    • Lime (CaO): 60–67%
    • Silica (SiO₂): 17–25%
    • Alumina (Al₂O₃): 3–8%
    • Iron oxide (Fe₂O₃): 0.5–6%
    • Magnesia, alkalis, and other oxides: minor amounts

question:
The Gulf of Khambhat, the Gulf of Kutch and Sundarbans region provide ideal conditions for utilizing ___________ energy in India.

SSC CGL 27/07/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• The Gulf of Khambhat, Gulf of Kutch, and Sundarbans are coastal regions in India where tidal energy potential is high due to significant tidal ranges and strong tidal currents.
  • These areas experience regular rise and fall of sea levels, making them ideal for harnessing tidal energy through tidal barrages or tidal turbines.
  • Tidal energy is a renewable, predictable, and environment-friendly energy source.
  • Other options:
    • Wind energy is more suitable for inland or elevated coastal areas (e.g., Tamil Nadu, Gujarat’s inland regions).
    • Thermal energy generally refers to geothermal or fossil-fuel based sources, not applicable here.
    • Solar energy is ideal for regions with high sun exposure, not necessarily coastal tidal zones.

Additional Information:

  • India’s first proposed tidal energy project was in the Gulf of Kutch.
  • The Sundarbans delta also shows potential for small-scale tidal power generation, though development is still in early stages.

question:
Which stone could convert all baser metals like iron into gold?

Higher Secondary 28/06/2023 ( Shift- 2)
solution:
• The Philosopher’s Stone is a legendary substance in alchemy, believed to have the power to transmute base metals (like iron or lead) into gold.
  • It was also thought to grant immortality through the creation of the elixir of life.
  • Although purely mythical and never discovered, it played a major role in medieval scientific thought and experiments.
  • Other options:
    • Emerald and Jade are precious gemstones, valued for beauty, not chemical properties.
    • Copper stone has no such mythological or alchemical relevance.

Additional Information:

  • The idea of the Philosopher’s Stone was central to the work of alchemists in ancient Greece, India, China, and the Islamic world.
  • It is symbolically linked to perfection, enlightenment, and transformation.

question:
Which is the oldest oil producing state of India?

Matric Level 30/06/2023 (Shift- 4)
solution:
• Assam is the oldest oil-producing state in India, where oil was first discovered and extracted in the late 19th century.
  • The first successful oil well was drilled in Digboi, Assam in 1889, making it the birthplace of India’s petroleum industry.
  • Digboi is often called the “Oil City of Assam” and houses one of the oldest refineries in the world still in operation.
  • Other options:
    • Gujarat is a major oil producer but began production much later (from the 1960s).
    • Maharashtra and Telangana are not historically known for oil production.

Additional Information:

  • Assam still contributes to India’s petroleum output, with major fields like Naharkatia, Moran, and Rudrasagar.
  • The oil industry in Assam is managed primarily by Oil India Limited (OIL) and ONGC.

question:
Kawas Thermal Power Station is located in which of the following states?

SSC MTS 04/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• The Kawas Thermal Power Station is located in the Surat district of Gujarat.
  • It is a gas-based combined cycle power plant operated by NTPC (National Thermal Power Corporation).
  • The plant uses natural gas as the primary fuel and is part of India’s strategy to diversify energy sources beyond coal.
  • Other options:
    • Maharashtra, West Bengal, and Rajasthan have thermal plants, but Kawas is specific to Gujarat.

Additional Information:

  • Kawas Power Station has an installed capacity of 645 MW.
  • It plays a key role in supplying electricity to the western grid of India.

question:
The main mineral constituents of the continental mass are ____ and _____ .

SSC MTS 08/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• The continental mass (also called Sial) refers to the upper layer of the Earth’s crust that forms the continents.
  • Its main mineral constituents are:
    • Silica (SiO₂)
    • Alumina (Al₂O₃)
  • These minerals are light and less dense, forming rocks like granite, which are typical of continental crust.
  • This layer is different from the oceanic crust, which is richer in silica and magnesium (Sima).

Additional Information:

  • The term Sial comes from Silica + Alumina, indicating its dominant composition.
  • Sial forms the continents, while Sima (Silica + Magnesium) makes up the ocean floor.

question:
Which state among the following has the largest reserves of gold ore in India as of 2021?

SSC CHSL 09/03/2023 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• As per the latest data from the Indian Bureau of Mines (2021), Bihar has the largest gold ore reserves in India, surpassing traditional producers like Karnataka.
  • A major discovery was made in the Sono area of Jamui district, where over 222 million tonnes of gold ore were estimated, making Bihar the top state in terms of gold ore quantity.
  • While Karnataka has been historically known for gold production (especially from Kolar and Hutti mines), Bihar now leads in terms of total ore reserves, not production.

Additional Information:

  • Kolar Gold Fields (Karnataka) are now closed, but Hutti Gold Mines still operate and contribute to gold production.
  • The gold in Bihar has not yet been commercially extracted, but exploration is ongoing under Geological Survey of India (GSI).

question:
Which of the following statements regarding coal is NOT correct?

SSC CHSL 14/03/2023 (2nd Shift)
option_1: Anthracite is the highest quality hard coal.
option_2: Coal that has been buried deep and subjected to increased temperatures is bituminous coal.
option_3: Lignite is a low-grade brown coal, which is soft with high moisture content.
option_4: Metallurgical coal is high grade lignite coal which has a special value for smelting iron in blast furnaces.
solution:
• Option (d) is NOT correct because it inaccurately describes metallurgical coal.
  • Metallurgical coal, also known as coking coal, is not lignite—it is a high-grade bituminous coal, specially used in the steel industry for smelting iron in blast furnaces.
  • Lignite, on the other hand, is a low-grade brown coal, soft and with high moisture, and is not suitable for metallurgical use.
  • The other options are correct:
    • (a) Anthracite is indeed the highest quality, hard and lustrous coal.
    • (b) Bituminous coal forms under higher pressure and temperature, typically found at greater depths.
    • (c) Lignite is a soft, moisture-rich brown coal and considered low-grade.

Additional Information:

  • Coking coal is essential for iron and steel making, as it forms coke that acts as both a fuel and a reducing agent in blast furnaces.
  • India imports coking coal, as its domestic reserves are limited and concentrated mainly in Jharkhand and Odisha.

question:
Which of the following is NOT a major iron ore belt in India?

SSC CHSL 17/03/2023 (2nd Shift)
option_4: Durg- Bastar- Chandrapur belt
solution:
• Option (b) – Haryana–Rajasthan belt is NOT a major iron ore belt in India.
  • This region is not geologically rich in iron ore deposits and is better known for other minerals like limestone, zinc, marble, and gypsum.
  • The other options are all recognized iron ore belts in India:
    • (a) Maharashtra–Goa belt: Includes Ratnagiri and North Goa regions, known for iron ore mining.
    • (c) Odisha–Jharkhand belt: Contains massive reserves in areas like Keonjhar, Barbil, Singhbhum, and Noamundi.
    • (d) Durg–Bastar–Chandrapur belt: Spreads across Chhattisgarh and Maharashtra, rich in high-grade hematite ore.

Additional Information:

  • India’s iron ore reserves are mostly concentrated in the eastern and central regions, especially in states like Odisha, Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Karnataka, and Goa.
  • These belts are crucial for India’s steel industry and export sector.

question:
The largest wind farm cluster of India is located in ______.

SSC CGL 07/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The largest wind farm cluster in India is located in the state of Tamil Nadu, specifically in the districts of Kanyakumari, Tirunelveli, and Thoothukudi.
  • The region around Muppandal in Kanyakumari district is home to India’s biggest wind farm cluster, with thousands of wind turbines spread across the hills and plains.
  • These wind farms benefit from the strong and consistent southwest monsoon winds and contribute significantly to renewable energy production in India.
  • Other states like Gujarat, Maharashtra, and Karnataka also have large wind farms, but Tamil Nadu leads in total installed capacity.

Additional Information:

  • Tamil Nadu contributes around 25% of India's total wind power capacity.
  • Muppandal Wind Farm is one of the largest onshore wind farms in Asia.

question:
The major resources of Gondwana coal, which are metallurgical coal is located in______.

SSC CGL 08/12/2022 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Damodar Valley is the major source of Gondwana coal in India, especially of metallurgical (coking) coal, which is essential for steel production.
  • This valley spans parts of Jharkhand and West Bengal, and hosts some of India’s richest coalfields like:
    • Jharia – India’s largest reserve of coking coal
    • Bokaro
    • Raniganj
  • The coal here belongs to the Gondwana geological formation, which dates back around 250 million years.
  • Other valleys listed:
    • Chambal, Krishna, and Narmada are not significant coal-producing regions, especially not for metallurgical coal.

Additional Information:

  • Metallurgical (coking) coal is used in blast furnaces for iron and steel making.
  • The Damodar Valley Corporation (DVC) also plays a vital role in regional power generation using this coal.

question:
Peat coal has ____ carbon and ____ moisture content?

SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Peat coal is the lowest grade of coal in terms of carbon content and energy efficiency.
  • It contains a very low percentage of carbon, typically around 50–60%, which results in low calorific value.
  • It has very high moisture content, which makes it smoke heavily and burn inefficiently.
  • Due to its poor quality, peat is considered more of a pre-coal stage and is rarely used commercially for power generation.

Correct Pairing:

  • Low carbon
  • High moisture

Additional Information:

  • Peat is formed from partially decayed plant matter in waterlogged conditions.
  • Over geological time, peat can transform into lignite, then bituminous, and eventually anthracite, with increasing carbon content.

question:
In which of the following states of India, the reserves of silver are NOT found?

SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Silver reserves in India are primarily found in Rajasthan, followed by Jharkhand, Odisha, and Andhra Pradesh.
  • These states have silver either as a primary or associated mineral with other ores like lead, zinc, and copper.
  • Gujarat, on the other hand, is not known for silver reserves, making it the correct answer.

State-wise presence:

  • Odisha: Silver occurs with lead and copper ores, especially in regions like Sundargarh.
  • Jharkhand: Found in Singhbhum region, associated with copper ore.
  • Andhra Pradesh: Has minor silver presence, especially in Cuddapah basin.
  • Gujarat: No significant silver reserves reported.

Additional Information:

  • The Sindesar Khurd and Zawar mines in Rajasthan are India's leading producers of silver.
  • Silver is mostly obtained as a by-product of refining lead, zinc, and copper ores.

question:
Which of the following is a large group of rock-forming silicate minerals that constitutes more than 50% of the Earth's crust and is widely used in the glass and ceramic industries?

SSC CHSL 6/06/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Feldspar is a large group of rock-forming silicate minerals that makes up over 50% of the Earth’s crust.
  • It consists primarily of aluminum silicates combined with potassium, sodium, or calcium.
  • Feldspars are extensively used in the glass and ceramic industries due to their fluxing properties, which help reduce the melting temperature of mixtures.
  • Other options:
    • Amphibole and Pyroxene are important rock-forming minerals but not as abundant as feldspar.
    • Zeolites are microporous minerals, used mainly in water purification and catalysis, not glass or ceramics.

Additional Information:

  • Types of feldspar include orthoclase (potassium feldspar), albite (sodium feldspar), and anorthite (calcium feldspar).
  • India has significant feldspar deposits in Rajasthan, Andhra Pradesh, and Tamil Nadu.

question:
Which of the following minerals is NOT found in rivers (alluvial placers) and on the coast, especially beaches (beach placers)?

SSC CHSL 10/06/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Alluvial placers and beach placers are deposits of heavy and resistant minerals that accumulate through natural sedimentation in riverbeds and coastal areas.
  • Minerals typically found in such placers include:
    • Gold – commonly found in river alluvium.
    • Tin (Cassiterite) – found in riverbeds.
    • Platinum – found in both alluvial and beach placers due to its high density and resistance to weathering.
  • Bauxite, however, is not found in placer deposits. It is a residual mineral formed through lateritic weathering of aluminum-rich rocks in upland tropical and subtropical areas, not in rivers or beaches.

Additional Information:

  • Bauxite is the primary ore of aluminum and is typically mined from surface deposits in plateau regions.
  • Major bauxite-producing states in India include Odisha, Gujarat, Maharashtra, and Jharkhand.

question:
Which of the following is an Export Processing Zone (EPZ) set up in West Bengal?

SSC MTS 08/10/2021 (Morning)
solution:
• The Falta Export Processing Zone (EPZ), now known as Falta Special Economic Zone (SEZ), is located in the state of West Bengal.
  • It was established to promote exports by offering infrastructure, tax incentives, and simplified customs procedures to export-oriented units.
  • Falta SEZ is managed by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry (Government of India) and supports industries like textiles, electronics, and leather goods.
  • Other options:
    • Farakka – known for its thermal power project, not an EPZ.
    • Haldia – an industrial port city but not designated as an EPZ.
    • Midnapur – a district, not a recognized EPZ location.

Additional Information:

  • Falta SEZ was one of the earliest EPZs established in India.
  • It has attracted both domestic and foreign investment, boosting employment and exports in eastern India.

question:
In which of the following states are the Sundargarh deposits of Manganese located?

SSC CPO 24/11/2020 (Evening)
solution:
• The Sundargarh deposits of manganese are located in the state of Odisha, which is one of India’s leading producers of manganese ore.
  • Sundargarh district, along with Keonjhar and Rayagada, contributes significantly to Odisha’s manganese production.
  • Manganese from this region is mainly used in the steel industry for making ferroalloys, which enhance hardness and strength.
  • Other options:
    • Maharashtra – also a manganese-producing state, especially Nagpur and Bhandara districts.
    • Kerala and Gujarat – have limited or no significant manganese reserves.

Additional Information:

  • Odisha accounts for around 30% of India’s total manganese production.
  • The manganese ore found in Sundargarh is often associated with iron ore formations, making the region mineral-rich.

question:
Which of the following states has one of the richest monazite deposits in India?

SSC CHSL 20/10/2020 (Evening)
solution:
• Monazite is a rare earth phosphate mineral that contains thorium and other rare earth elements, making it radioactive and strategically important.
  • The richest deposits of monazite in India are found in the coastal sands of Kerala, especially in districts like Alappuzha, Kollam, and Thiruvananthapuram.
  • These are known as beach placers, where monazite occurs along with other heavy minerals like ilmenite, rutile, and zircon.
  • Other states like Gujarat, Jharkhand, and Rajasthan do not have significant monazite reserves.

Additional Information:

  • India’s monazite reserves are mainly controlled by Indian Rare Earths Limited (IREL).
  • Kerala alone contributes over 60% of India’s monazite resources, making it vital for nuclear energy and rare earth extraction.
